factoid: Pierre was well aware of the large room divided by columns and an arch.
The walls of the room were hung round with Persian carpets.
The part of the room behind the columns contained a high silk-curtained mahogany bedstead on one side.
The part of the room behind the columns contained an immense case containing icons on the other side.
The room was brightly illuminated with red light like a Russian church during evening service.
The icons were brightly illuminated with red light.
Under the gleaming icons stood a long invalid chair.
The invalid chair was occupied by Pierre's father, Count Bezúkhov.
Count Bezúkhov lay under the icons.
Count Bezúkhov had a gray mane of hair above his broad forehead.
Count Bezúkhov had deep characteristically noble wrinkles on his handsome, ruddy face.
Count Bezúkhov's large thick hands were outside the green quilt.
The wax taper was thrust between Count Bezúkhov's forefinger and thumb.
An old servant was bending over from behind the chair and held the wax taper in position.
Priests stood by the chair.
The priests had long hair falling over their magnificent glittering vestments.
The priests held lighted tapers in their hands.
The priests were conducting the service slowly and solemnly.
Two younger princesses stood a little behind the priests holding handkerchiefs to their eyes.
Catiche, the eldest sister, stood just in front of the younger princesses.
Catiche had a vicious and determined look steadily fixed on the icons.
Catiche seemed to declare that she could not answer for herself if she glanced round.
Anna Mikháylovna stood by the door near the strange lady.
Prince Vasíli stood in front of the door near the invalid chair.
Prince Vasíli had a wax taper in his left hand.
Prince Vasíli leaned his left arm on the carved back of a velvet chair he had turned round for the purpose.
Prince Vasíli was crossing himself with his right hand.
Prince Vasíli turned his eyes upward each time he touched his forehead.
Prince Vasíli's face wore a calm look of piety and resignation to the will of God.
Prince Vasíli seemed to say, "If you do not understand these sentiments, so much the worse for you!"
Behind Prince Vasíli stood the aide‑de‑camp, the doctors, and the menservants.
The men and women had separated as in church.
All were silently crossing themselves.
The reading of the church service was being heard.
The subdued chanting of deep bass voices was being heard.
In the intervals, sighs and shuffling of feet were the only sounds that could be heard.
Anna Mikháylovna had an air of importance that showed she felt she quite knew what she was about.
Anna Mikháylovna went across the room to where Pierre was standing.
Anna Mikháylovna gave Pierre a taper.
Pierre lit the taper.
Pierre was distracted by observing those around him.
Pierre began crossing himself with the hand that held the taper.
The strange lady was near the door where Anna Mikháylovna stood.
The pillows on the invalid chair were snowy‑white and smooth.
The green quilt covered Count Bezúkhov to the waist.
